title: Cat. 48  Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Trajan, A.D. 114/15
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Trajan  
A.D. 114/15, issued by Trajan  
Gold; diam. 2 cm; 7.36 g  
Mint: Rome  
Obverse: Bust of Trajan right, laureate, cuirass and paludamentum  
Inscribed: IMP CAES NER TRAIANO OPTIMO AVG GER DAC  
Reverse: Trajan, seated on sella castrensis on raised dais, hand resting on parazonium, with two officers standing behind him, establishes three client kings dressed in trousers  
Inscribed: REGNA.ADSIGNATA  
RIC II 367; BMCRE III 588; axis: 6:00  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Martin A. Ryerson, 1922.4871

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">The obverse legend supports the accompanying image of Trajan in cuirass and paludamentum, the garb of the Roman general. In the form of an honorific dedication, it says “[To] the emperor, Caesar Nerva Trajan, the Best, Augustus, [the conqueror of] Germany and Dacia.” The phrase optimus princeps, the Best Prince, had already appeared on coins as early as A.D. 103: see cat. 47, Denarius (Coin) Portraying Emperor Trajan. Here, however, it appears in a formal position as part of the emperor’s name (TRAIANO OPTIMO, in the dative case). This means that the coin must date from 114 at the earliest, when the Senate bestowed this distinctive honor on him.

Trajan left an impressive legacy of social welfare programs and building campaigns in Rome, but his coinage focused on his expansion of the Roman Empire. The majority of the coin types reflect the Dacian campaigns, but this coin reflects Rome’s eager anticipation of yet another addition to Rome’s provincial satellites. Minted in Rome, it imagines the scene as Trajan confirms three unidentified client kings (“kingdoms assigned,” as the reverse inscription declares) in the area of Mesopotamia, as part of his preparations for the great campaign against Parthia. Trajan later received the title Parthicus by decree of the Senate while he was still campaigning in the East, dealing with the backlash of revolts by some of those client kings (Seleucia and Judea). He died in 117 in Selinus in Cilicia, only sixty-four years old but worn out and ill, leaving the volatile situation in Parthia to be dealt with by his successor, Hadrian.  
Theresa Gross-Diaz

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Bennett, Trajan, p. 212.

This was in early summer 116; this coin predates that, since that title does not appear.
